title: Aston Martin shares dive another 6% in disastrous first year after float
text:
Aston Martin shares slumped another 6 per cent yesterday as it capped off a torrid first year as a public company.

Britain's only listed car maker floated at 1900p a year ago today – but has plunged 75 per cent since and last night closed at just 478p.

If someone had invested £1,000 in the float last year, they would have just £250 now.

Float flop: Aston Martin floated at 1900p a year ago today – but has plunged 75 per cent since and last night closed at just 478p

The luxury car group was worth £4.3billion when it first listed, but its market value has plunged to £1.1billion, meaning it has lost £8.8million every day for a year.

Before the firm went public, chief executive Andy Palmer said: 'We don't make cars, we make dreams.'

Palmer has been at Aston's helm since 2014.

Under his tenure the James Bond favourite has been hit by disappointing updates, rescue financings and a loss of investor confidence since the float, which analysts say was far overpriced.

Costs from the listing have weighed on profits and, back in February, the firm posted an annual loss of £68million for 2018, which compared with profit of £85million the year before.

In July its share price nosedived after it warned it will sell fewer cars this year than it initially thought.

Last month it was forced to pay huge interest rates to borrow an extra £120million to shore up its books at short notice, which AJ Bell's investment director Russ Mould deemed a 'major red flag'.

It is pinning its hopes on its first SUV, the family-targeted DBX, which is due to be released by the end of the year.

Aston has gone bust seven times in its 106-year history.
